case_name: State of Maharashtra v. Mayor of the Nagpur Municipal Corporation

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2340 of 1966 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2340 of 1966. Appeal from the judgment and order dated

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated October 7, 1966 of Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench in Special Civil Application No. 940 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 7, 1966 of the Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench in Special Civil Appli- cation No. 940 of 1965.

facts.text: Writ petition filed by respondent No. 1 before Nagpur Bench of Bombay High Court challenging show-cause notice dated July 21, 1965 and order dated September 29, 1965 superseding Nagpur Municipal Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of a writ petition filed by respondent No. 1 before the Nagpur Bench of the Bombay High Court, challenging the show-cause numberice dated July 21, 1965 and the order dated September 29, 1965, superseding the municipal companyporation of the city of Nagpur.

facts.text: Term of office of present Councillors commenced in July 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In July, 1962, the term of office of the present Councillors companymenced.

facts.text: Government of Maharashtra issued show-cause notice dated July 21, 1965 to respondent No. 1, the Mayor of Nagpur Municipal Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: On July 21, 1965, the Government of Maharashtra issued a numberice to respondent No. 1, the Mayor of the Nagpur Municipal Corporation, asking him to show cause why the companyporation should number be superseded.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed reply to show-cause notice on August 1, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: On August 1, 1965, respondent No. I filed his reply to the show-cause numberice.

facts.text: State Government passed order dated September 29, 1965 superseding the Corporation under sections 408 and 409 of City of Nagpur Corporation Act 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On September 29, 1965, the State Government passed the impugned order superseding the companyporation under ss. 408 and 409 of the City of Nagpur Corporation Act 1948  C. P. Berar Act 11 of 1950 .

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed writ petition on September 30, 1965 challenging show-cause notice and supersession order.

anchor.surface_text: On September 30, 1965, respondent No. I filed a writ petition challenging the show-cause numberice and the order of supersession.

facts.text: High Court allowed writ petition and quashed supersession order on October 7, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the writ petition and quashed the order of supersession.

facts.text: High Court held that State Government exercised power under S.408 on grounds not reasonably related and finding rationally impossible.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the State Government exercised its power under S. 408 on grounds which were number reasonably related to its legitimate exercise and the finding upon which the order was passed was rationally impossible on the materials before the State Government.

facts.text: State of Maharashtra appeals to Supreme Court on certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Maharashtra number appeals to this Court on a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Administrator appointed under supersession order joined as second appellant by Supreme Court order.

anchor.surface_text: By an order of this Court, the Administrator of the City of Nagpur appointed under the order of supersession of September 29, 1965, has been joined as the second appellant.

facts.text: Free cash balance of Corporation was Rs. 5.81 lacs approximately in March 1962.

anchor.surface_text: that the free cash balance of Rs. 5.81 lacs approximately in March 1962 was reduced to Rs. 53,000 approximately on the 12th July, 1965

facts.text: Free cash balance reduced to Rs. 53,000 approximately on July 12, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: has neglected to under take the improvement of water supply and to provide a sufficient supply of suitable water for public and private purposes

facts.text: Kanhan Stage III work commenced in 1964; Government sanctioned ad hoc loan of Rs.21 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: The work at Kanhan Stage.111 companymenced in 1964 and. for that purpose the Government sanctioned an ad hoc loan of Rs. 21 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: The companyt of the remaining work at Kanhan Stage III and the work of re-modelling and redesigning of distribution system was estimated to be Rs. 70 lacs.

facts.text: Standing Committee resolved on June 5, 1965 to raise Rs.70 lacs loan and accept universal meterisation and separate water budget.

anchor.surface_text: On June 5, 1965, the standing companymittee resolved The Corporation may raise in the open market loan of Rs. 70 lacs for the purpose of companypleting the Kanhan Stage III head works

facts.text: Corporation disapproved Standing Committee's resolution on universal meterisation and separate budget at meeting on June 30, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: At a meeting held on June 30, 1965, the companyporation appears to have disapproved of the standing companymittees resolution regarding the principle of universal meterisation

facts.text: Corporation meeting on July 5, 1965 to discuss Rs.70 lacs loan was adjourned.

anchor.surface_text: On July 5, 1965, the meeting was adjourned.

facts.text: Corporation passed resolution on July 12, 1965 approving raising Rs.70 lacs loan in next three years.

anchor.surface_text: On July 1,2, 1965, the companyporation passed the, following resolution- The Corporation gives its approval to the raising of a loan of Rs. 70 lakhs, in the next three years.

facts.text: Supreme Court held first ground for supersession (financial) invalid due to no opportunity and irrational finding.

anchor.surface_text: The opinion of the State, government so far as it is based on the first ground cannot be supported.

facts.text: Supreme Court held second ground (water supply neglect) valid and sufficient for supersession order.

facts.text: Supersession order dated September 29, 1965 directs Councillors to retire from October 1, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: directs that all the Councillors of the Municipal Corporation shall retire from office as and from the 1st day of October, 1965

facts.text: Shri D. H. Deshmukh appointed Administrator from October 1, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: appoints Shri D. H. Deshmukh to be the Administrator of the City of Nagpur

facts.text: Water supply in Nagpur was inadequate; population fast increasing.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the water supply of the city of Nagpur was inadequate. The population of the city was fast increasing

facts.text: Government conditions for loan guarantee: immediate meterisation and separate water works budget.

anchor.surface_text: The Government was willing to give the guarantee if two companyditions were fulfilled  1  the companyoration would meter the water supply immediately, and  2  in the annual budget, the budget of the water works department

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld supersession order as valid based on second ground alone.

arguments.claim: The State Government exercised its power under S. 408 on grounds which were not reasonably related to its legitimate exercise and the finding upon which the order was passed was rationally impossible on the materials before the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the State Government exercised its power under S. 408 on grounds which were not reasonably related to its legitimate exercise and the finding upon which the order was passed was rationally impossible on the materials before the State Government.

arguments.claim: The order under s. 408 is liable to be set aside if no reasonable person on a proper consideration of the materials before the State government could form the opinion that the corporation is not competent to perform, or persistently makes default in the performance of the duties imposed on it by or under this Act or any other law for the time being in force, or exceeds or abuses its powers.

anchor.surface_text: But the order is liable to be set aside if no reasonable person on a proper consideration of the materials before the State government could form the opinion that the corporation is not competent to perform, or persistently makes default in the performance of the duties imposed on it by or under this Act or any other law for the time being in force, or exceeds or abuses its powers.

arguments.claim: The State government must give to the corporation an opportunity to show cause why the order under the section should not be made, except in cases of emergency.

anchor.surface_text: Except in cases of emergency, the State government must give to the corporation an opportunity to show cause why the order under the section should not be made.

arguments.claim: The opinion of the State government so far as it is based on the first ground (financial mismanagement) cannot be supported because no opportunity was given to the corporation to explain the specific charges and no reasonable person could form the opinion on the materials.

anchor.surface_text: The opinion of the State, government so far as it is based on the first ground cannot be supported. The show-cause notice did not mention the charge that the Councillors planned the expenditure on the basis of uncertain receipts or that they did not exercise proper controls provided by or under the Act.

holdings.text: Except in cases of emergency, the State government must give to the corporation an opportunity to show cause why the order under the section should not be made.

anchor.surface_text: Except in cases of emerge icy, the State government must give to the companyporation an opportunity to show cause why the order under the section should number be made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly from interpretation of s.408(1); mandatory unless emergency; opportunity given here but inadequate for specific charges.

holdings.text: The order under s.408 is liable to be set aside if no reasonable person on a proper consideration of the materials before the State government could form the opinion that the corporation is not competent to perform, or persistently makes default in the performance of the duties imposed on it by or under this Act or any other law for the time being in force, or exceeds or abuses its powers.

anchor.surface_text: But the order is liable to be set aside if no reasonable person on a proper consideration of the materials before the State government could form the opinion that the corporation is not competent to perform, or persistently makes default in the performance of the duties imposed on it by or under this Act or any other law for the time being in force, or exceeds or abuses its powers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial review limited to Wednesbury unreasonableness; court not appellate on facts.

holdings.text: The point whether the order under s. 408 is quasi-judicial or administrative act is not very material, for it is common ground that the present case was not one of emergency and the State government was bound to give opportunity to the corporation to show cause why the order should not be made.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether the order under s. 408 is an administrative or quasi-judicial act, our attention was drawn to the decisions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction immaterial as opportunity required regardless; references to prior cases not decisive here.

holdings.text: The opinion of the State government so far as it is based on the first ground cannot be supported.

anchor.surface_text: The opinion of the State, government so far as it is based on the first ground cannot be supported. The show-cause notice did not mention the charge that the Councillors planned the expenditure on the basis of uncertain receipts or that they did not exercise proper controls provided by or under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No opportunity on specific charges of planning on uncertain receipts/control failure; cash balance variation insufficient; salaries paid; resolution post-notice.

holdings.text: There were materials before the State Government upon which it could find that the corporation had neglected to undertake an improvement of water supply and to provide a sufficient supply of suitable water for public and private purposes.

anchor.surface_text: There were materials be ore the State Government upon which it companyld find that the companyporation had neglected to undertake an improvement of water supply

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inadequate supply admitted; necessary works required loan with reasonable conditions (meterisation, separate budget); corporation disapproved/rejected via resolutions.

holdings.text: In this background, the State government could reasonably hold that the passing of the resolution excluding the office note amounted to virtual rejection of the conditions mentioned in the note.

anchor.surface_text: In this background, the State government. companyld reasonably hold that the passing of the resolution excluding the office numbere amounted to virtual rejection of the companyditions mentioned in the numbere.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resolution July 12 excluded conditions despite prior disapproval June 30; no mention of further negotiations or extra loan need in resolution/reply.

holdings.text: An administrative or quasi-judicial order based on several grounds, all taken together, cannot be sustained if it be found that some of the grounds are non-existent or irrelevant, and there is nothing to show that the authority would have passed the order on the basis of the other relevant and existing grounds. On the other hand, an order based on several grounds some of which are found to be non-existent or irrelevant, can be sustained if the court is satisfied that the authority would have passed the order on the basis of the other relevant and existing grounds, and the exclusion of the irrelevant or non-existent grounds could not have affected the ultimate opinion or decision.

anchor.surface_text: An administrative or quasi-judicial order based on several grounds, all taken together, cannot be sustained if it be found that some of the grounds are number-existent or irrelevant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle from detention/tribunal cases; applicable but distinguished as grounds joint/several, second alone serious/sufficient; govt would have acted anyway.

holdings.text: The order dated September 29, 1965, read with the notice dated July 21, 1965 shows that in the opinion of the State government the second ground alone was serious enough to warrant action under s. 408(1) and was sufficient to establish that the corporation was not competent to perform its duties under the Act. The fact that the first ground mentioned in the order is not found to exist and is irrelevant, does not affect the order. We are reasonably certain that the State government would have passed the order on the basis of the second ground alone. The order is, therefore, valid and cannot be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The order dated September 29, 1965, read with the numberice dated July 21, 1965 shows that in the opinion of the State government the second ground alone was serious enough to warrant action under s. 408 1  and was sufficient... The order is, therefore, valid and cannot be set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notice stated grounds joint/severally serious; second ground alone warranted supersession; certain govt would have acted on it independently.

precedents.citation: Dwarka Dass Bhatia v. The State of Jammu and Kashmir  1

anchor.surface_text: Dwarka Dass Bhatia v. The State of Jammu and Kashmir  1  said The principle underlying all these decisions is this. Where power is vested in a statutory authority to deprive the liberty of a subject on its subjective satisfaction with reference to specified matters, if that satisfaction is stated to be based on a number of grounds or for a variety of reasons all taken together, and if some out of them are found to be number-existent or irrelevant, the very exercise of that power is bad.

precedents.case_name: Dwarka Dass Bhatia v. State of Jammu and Kashmir
precedents.cited_proposition: principle that order based on subjective satisfaction with multiple grounds is invalid if some grounds are non-existent or irrelevant unless exclusion would not affect the decision
precedents.cited_holding: Where power is vested in a statutory authority to deprive the liberty of a subject on its subjective satisfaction with reference to specified matters, if that satisfaction is stated to be based on a number of grounds or for a variety of reasons all taken together, and if some out of them are found to be non-existent or irrelevant, the very exercise of that power is bad.

precedents.citation: Maursinha v. State of Madhya Pradesh 1

anchor.surface_text: Maursinha v. State of Madhya Pradesh 1 , the Madhya Pradesh High Court, following the principle of the preventive detention cases, held that an order of supersession of the municipality under s. 208 of the Madhya Bharat Municipal ties Act 1954, based on several grounds, most of which were found to be irrelevant, was invalid.

precedents.case_name: Maursinha v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: order of supersession invalid if based on several grounds most of which irrelevant, following preventive detention principle

precedents.citation: Dhirajlal Girdharilal v. Commissioner of Income-tax 2

anchor.surface_text: Dhirajlal Girdharilal v. Commissioner of Income-tax 2  Mahajan, C. J., said with reference to the order of an income-tax tribunal The learned Attorney-General frankly companyceded that it companyld number be denied that to a certain extent the Tribunal had drawn upon its own imagination and had made use of a number of surmises and companyjectures in reaching its result.

precedents.case_name: Dhirajlal Girdharilal v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: finding vitiated if court acts on partly relevant and partly irrelevant material
precedents.cited_holding: when a court of facts acts on material, partly relevant and partly irrelevant, it is impossible to say to what extent the mind of the court was affected by the irrelevant material used by it in arriving at its finding

precedents.citation: State of Orissa v. Bidyabhushan Mahapatra 3

anchor.surface_text: State of Orissa v. Bidyabhushan Mahapatra 3  an administrative tribunal in a disciplinary proceeding against a public servant found the second charge and four out of the five heads under the first charge proved and recommended his dismissal.

precedents.case_name: State of Orissa v. Bidyabhushan Mahapatra
precedents.cited_proposition: order of dismissal sustainable if supported by some findings of substantial misdemeanour even if not all findings sustainable
precedents.cited_holding: if the order may be supported on any finding as to substantial misdemeanour for which the punishment can lawfully be imposed, it is not for the Court to consider whether that ground alone would have weighed with the authority
